description.narrative: Contribute to achieve the following targets of MSI global strategy:  Double the number of women, men and young people using contraception supplied by MSI to 40 million  Double our annual medical abortion and medical post abortion care provision to 6 million  Remove 30 high impact policy restrictions that limit access to SRHR

participating-org.narrative: Centro de Promocion y Defensa de los Derechos Sexuales y Reproductivos
International Campaign Women´s Right to Safe Abortion

recipient-region.narrative: Global core grant for Sub-Saharan countries and fragile states

transaction.ref: Invoice Reference: MSI 2 To continue activities a
INTERNATIONAL CAMPAIGN FOR WOMEN'S RGHT TO SAFE A

description.narrative: MSI has several ongoing studies to address key research questions, including: 1. How can MSI increase FP uptake (especially LARCs) by high-impact clients? 2. How can country programmes effectively decrease FP discontinuation and/or increase switching to LARCs? 3. How do women seek abortion and how can MSI support their decision-making? 4. How can MSI ensure that its abortion clients receive and continue to use contraception (PAFP)? 5. How can task-sharing for FP and abortion improve MSI’s programme impact? 6. How can MSI improve measurement of client satisfaction and experience? 7. How cam MSI improve the client experience and outcomes of self-managed MA? 8. How can MSI improve its clinical abortion care, including pain management, cervical priming for D&E, and promoting adherence to the regimen? 9. How can MSI reduce provider bias and increase client engagement in decision-making for FP & abortion? 10. How can service diversification and cross-selling contribute to sustainability of operations and core service maximisation (FP/SA)? 11. How can community-based providers, including MS Ladies, contribute to programme sustainability? 12. How can public sector purchasing of MSI services within a ‘Universal Health Coverage’ framework impact programme sustainability and health outcomes?

title.narrative: Significant demonstrable progress on 3-4 of MSI priority research questions and at least one article published annually, with a strong focus on access, equity and youth, women agency and task sharing.

comment.narrative: Targets are set on an annual basis. We start counting from "0" on 1 January of every year.

MSI has several ongoing studies to address key research questions, including: 1) How can MSI increase FP uptake (especially LARCs) by high-impact clients? 3) How do women seek abortion and how can MSI support their decision-making? 4) How can MSI ensure that its abortion clients receive and continue to use contraception (PAFP)? 5) How can task-sharing for FP and abortion improve MSI’s programme impact? 7) How can MSI improve the client experience and outcomes of self-managed MA? 11) How can community-based providers, including MS Ladies, contribute to programme sustainability? Significant progress has been made during the publicaiton period on all the above studies.

title.narrative: Significant demonstrable progress on 3-4 of MSI priority research questions and at least one article published annually, with a strong focus on access, equity and youth, women agency and task sharing.

comment.narrative: Targets are set on an annual basis. We start counting from "0" on 1 January of every year.

Study 1: Unintended consequences of mHealth interactive voice messages targeting post-menstrual regulation contraceptive use in Bangladesh: Intimate partner violence Study 2: Drug Seller Provision Practices and Knowledge of Misoprostol in Bangladesh Study 3: Understanding women’s experiences with abortion complications in clinic settings where unsafe abortion persists Study 4: Evaluation of the Implementation of the Client Centre Care Package aimed at improving client satisfaction in Marie Stopes centres in Nepal Study 5: Using a call centre to support self-administration of mifepristone and misoprostol in Bangladesh: a harm reduction approach Study 6: Understanding women’s experiences with abortion complications and side effects from self-managed medical abortion Study 7: Using a call centre to support self-administration of mifepristone and misoprostol in Bangladesh: a harm reduction approach Study 8: Evaluating an intervention to increase use of call centre support for self-managed medical abortion, Lusaka Zambia Study 9: Evaluation of values clarification and attitude transformation workshops on service provision and client experience, Ethiopia

title.narrative: Number of policy restrictions removed (one annually) that limit access to contraception and/or safe abortion, or significant progress towards removal, improvement or implementation of relevant policies.

comment.narrative: Targets are set on an annual basis. We start counting from "0" on 1 January of every year.

Ethiopia - Civil Society Proclamation (Charity Law) passed which legislates Income Generation Activity Q1 Nepal - First contract secured for private/NGO provision of an FP method (vasectomy) Q1 Kenya - New PAC Guidelines secured Q1 Nigeria - Inclusion of Misoprostol and Mifepristone on the Essential Drugs List Q2 Kenya - Increased resource allocation for FP secured in Mombasa County and Nakuru County Q3 Bangladesh - Tubal hook authorised for TLs Q3 Mongolia - Revised National Safe Abortion Care Guidelines approved (eligible private providers can now provide MA up to 9 weeks) Q3 Madagascar - Removal of import tax on contraceptives (Finance Act passed) Q4 Niger - Presidential Decree secured to implement Reproductive Health Law ensuring this is now binding law and to enhance community-based distribution of FP services. Q3 Tanzania - Inclusion of misoprostol in CPAC in HMS tool Q4 Uganda - Mariprist registered Q4

title.narrative: Fragile States: Comprehensive Abortion Care / Post Abortion Care delivered (CAC/PAC)

title.narrative: Number of policy restrictions removed (one annually) that limit access to contraception and/or safe abortion, or significant progress towards removal, improvement or implementation of relevant policies.

comment.narrative: Targets are set on an annual basis. We start counting from "0" on 1 January of every year.

Madagascar – DMPA SC approved for self-injection and MoH guidance that authorises self injection and the regulatory conditions under which it can take place (Q1) Burkina Faso - Increase in the Family Planning budget line from 800,000,000 in 2019 to 900,000 CFA in 2020 (Q1) Kenya - PAC Package (guidelines, training and supportive supervision curriculums for task sharing of PAC) approved by the Ministry of Health (Q1) UK – Temporary approval for Medical Abortion at home through telemedicine (Q1) Nepal – Interim RH in COVID-19 Guidelines signed off. MSI’s programme in Nepal played an active role in a coordinated response between government, NGOs and multi-lateral organisations, to ensure that women in the country were able to continue accessing essential SRHR services, even in the context of a strict Covid-19 lockdown (Q2) Kenya – RH Covid Strategy launched (includes telemedicine for STM and potentially PAC) (Q2) Mali - Reproductive Health Strategic Plan 2020-2024 has a strategic objective and indicators on Adolescent Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights for the first time (Q4) Nepal – RH Regulations amended so that MA can be delivered outside of registered facilities (in homes, etc) (Q4) Malawi - New CAC Guidelines (Q4)

title.narrative: Number of policy restrictions removed (one annually) that limit access to contraception and/or safe abortion, or significant progress towards removal, improvement or implementation of relevant policies.

comment.narrative: Targets are set on an annual basis. We start counting from "0" on 1 January of every year.

1. Uganda - FP included in NHIS (Q1) 2. India - Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MPT) Act amended, dropping 'married' from indications; increasing gestation limit to 24 weeks for vulnerable women; including a confidentiality clause for pregnant women; and removing the upper gestation limit for foetal abnormalities subject to medical board approval (Q1) 3. Bangladesh - Changes in guidance on anaesthetics for pre-medication in tubal ligation operations. The National Technical Committee of the Directorate-General of Family Planning approved to waive the use of 'cocktail analgesia' (a combination of three durgs) for tubal ligations to ensure client safety and comfort and to ease the burden on FP resources (Q1) 4. Ghana Clinical methods of FP commodities and services approved for inclusion in the National Health Insurance Scheme (Q4) 5.Uganda Parliament passed the National Health Insurance Act which included FP in the basic package (Q4) 6. Zambia Ministry of Health approved changes to the National Demographic Health System Information to permit FP data collection for adolescents under 15 (Q4) 7. Sierra Leone Ministry of Education approved the inclusion of Comprehensive Sexuality Education in the National School Curriculum (Q4) 8. Ethiopia Ministry of Health revised second trimester abortion training guidance to task sharing to health officers, nurses and midwives.(Q4) 9. UK Public Spaces Protection Order around the MSI clinic in Ealing renewed. (Q4) 10. South Australia Termination of Pregnancy Act 2021 revised to decriminalise abortion/ b Public Health Access Amendment Act revised to permit abortion safe access zones (Q4)
